mikebart wrote:

post.author: Dinky
post.body:
efx wrote:
mikebart wrote:
how did you go about modeling those ornaments?


That's what I would like to know!


The ornaments look easy. The harder part that I see is that really neat patterned cylinder that's in the archway in the top area of the windows (the upside-down "U" shaped thing). Everything else looks pretty simple, but still very well done.

I always love it when people import models into Doom 3 for map editing, it's SO much better than those blocky brushes that the Radiant editor makes. But I have seen a lot of people make some really neat looking things with those brushes!

I still prefer neat imports .

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body: Looks good. Nice meshes.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
The patterened cylinder wasn't so bad, it's those curly leaf things that kill me. They're going to be problematic when I bake down to the low-poly, so I'll most likely have to redo them.

@mikebart- using modo, will try to work in some mudbox

The cylinder started out straight with 8 lengthwise edges and 22 segments. I pulled the lengthwise edges up and down to make the zig-zags in the segment edges. Then I beveled the zig-zags to make the cuts. I used the bend deformer to turn it into a half circle, then attached two straight segments to the ends to make a U. It's a sub-d model, so I can get away with fewer edges and still get round (at least until I'm done).

I didn't get the spacing quite right, so they look a litle busy- if i get the nerve to redo them I'll take some screens along the way.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body: Does anyone know what the max texture size d3 allows? I'm thinking of doing the whole wall with one texture- will 4096 texture sheets make it barf?

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
parsonsbear wrote:
The patterened cylinder wasn't so bad, it's those curly leaf things that kill me. They're going to be problematic when I bake down to the low-poly, so I'll most likely have to redo them.


I used alpha channelled geometry projected from the high poly models for the small details of the ornament on my low poly model just to get the shape of the edges without puting too many polys into it, but I think your column will project quite nicely as long as you fill the void.

post.author: Dinky
post.body:
parsonsbear wrote:
Does anyone know what the max texture size d3 allows? I'm thinking of doing the whole wall with one texture- will 4096 texture sheets make it barf?


I think 1024x1024 is the max. It can also accept 256x256 and 512x512.

I'm not 100% sure though, as I've never tried above 1024x1024.

post.author: The Happy Friar
post.body:
i've never tried above 1024x768 either.

just make sure the wall isn't one large brush though. Break it up in to several.

post.body:
mikebart wrote:
ive gone up to 2048x2048, I thought it depends on your video/texture memory

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body: wow that's a heck of a reference, thanks. I think I'm shooting for a new but not so fancy machine spec... maybe if it qualifies for d3 high quality that's cool- min 256 vram? I figure by the time I finish this d3 will be gpl and everyone will have a better machine than my laptop.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
new shots:







and some bad weather:

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
looks good, how did you go about making the snow?
If you're doing this for etqw the textures are probably good but if its for a portfolio project or something i'd crank the resolution up a bit.

where does the ornamental scrolling fit into those shots? is it a seperate building?

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
The snow is two particle effects, one custom (the falling dots) and the drifting is a recolored id particle.

The ornamental stuff is the main building, this is kinda like the shed. I'm doing this one first to get a feel for texture scale and in-game proportions. I can iterate over this one a lot quicker than the heavy one. The tower wall texture is giving me trouble- It's like a stucco, and the map is a lot more detailed than that, but it gets all blurry as you move away from it. I'll post images of the texture and some screens to illustrate later. The bricks are really tiling poorly, need better bump.

At this point I'm probably going to start over on it to fix a lot of the mistakes I made along the way. I have a better idea of how i need to deviate from reference to get the most out of the engine, as d3 is going to require a specific look- umm, dark. Not that it can't do lit, but it just looks really good with the lights off and the flashlight under it's face, so to speak.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
yeah you've definitly done a nice job of setting it up for a night scene, just one other thing I noticed this morning is the alpha planes on the trees dont look very cleen it looks like you painted the alphachannel with an airbrush, but im sure you're aware of them, you could probably get away them being all modeled.

I think the bricks need a sharper normalmap, Id suggest projecting it from a high poly model and give it some variation, I imagine you're going to be doing alot of projecting anyway with the scrolling ornaments.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
The bricks did get projected from geom, but the bevels need to be tighter, also got pulled into a sculpter and blurred them with a smooth brush while stamping, just playing around.

The alphas on the trees are a lot sharper than that, but they get downsampled at distance so they turn blurry- for these, the geom is probably enough, but that won't work for the pines.

dropped a new skybox and starting to test ground work:

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thats looking very nice for a test, do you think you could get the red light to reflect down along the road? I wonder if you could somehow create the illusion of anisotropic reflection.
which of those trees are modelled and which are in the background. can you show some wires of that shot?
looking good man

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
thanks for the encouragement! working on this thing feels dead slow sometimes. I don't think there's any modeled trees in that frame, just skybox. I'll post some more pics tomorrow when I get back to my PC.



I'm definitely excited about the ground stuff, i think I can get some very megatexture looking effects foregoing the per-pixel lighting.

The reflections across the icier, packed down parts of the path would be cool. I saw ATI's 'Toyshop' demo at Siggraph last year and it was bananas with that stuff. I wish I had more time to get into the shader programming, but maybe i can fake it somehow.

post.author: parsonsbear
Bo$bevok
post.body: cool

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
its a nice model but is that screen only showing the normal map? have you worked on the other maps too?

I can tell its not finished but, what is it? is it a giant spotlight? part of a telescope?

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
Yep- just normalmap (actually some parts don't even have that, or a faint white/grey grid for uv). It's a telescope, but a newer/smaller design than the others I'm working on. I had to put a screen up just so i could call it a night on the thing. It's been a, uh, learning experience. It looks very different ingame from the modeling app. Texture resolution is killing me too- I want to put lots of details into models, but a too high res bumpmap often gets blurry when viewed from far away, and compressed/jaggy looking when close up.

I'm going to make another pass at it soon, but i may put up a detailed list of these issues to try and get some help on it.

post.author: parsonsbear
mikebart
post.body:
Thats so cool , nice attention to detail and its such a great idea, I can really see why you chose this for a subject now.

I dont know what you've got planned for the sky but I think you could make it a bit more interesting, perhaps a higher resolution skybox? or maybe you could replace the skybox with an inverted sphere and have it slowly rotate on 2 axis
(did you mention earlier the stars were accurate?)

The telescope looks cool and the shadows make some interesting Silhouette's and the slide show's a great idea are you trying to make this educational?

Nice job man

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
thanks for checking in- not sure about educational, but certanly documentary.

the skybox is a pregenerated and correct for that lattitude and longitude, but the date is sometime ago. I've done tests with portalsky setups for drawing grids and stars, and will probably move over to that. I'm really into the batching topic going on right now, because the visible star count exceeds the max entity count, so if i'm generating accurate skies on the fly i need to take that into account. Either that or some kind of pixel shader for the stars.

where does the ornamental scrolling fit into those shots? is it a seperate building?

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
The snow is two particle effects, one custom (the falling dots) and the drifting is a recolored id particle.

The ornamental stuff is the main building, this is kinda like the shed. I'm doing this one first to get a feel for texture scale and in-game proportions. I can iterate over this one a lot quicker than the heavy one. The tower wall texture is giving me trouble- It's like a stucco, and the map is a lot more detailed than that, but it gets all blurry as you move away from it. I'll post images of the texture and some screens to illustrate later. The bricks are really tiling poorly, need better bump.

At this point I'm probably going to start over on it to fix a lot of the mistakes I made along the way. I have a better idea of how i need to deviate from reference to get the most out of the engine, as d3 is going to require a specific look- umm, dark. Not that it can't do lit, but it just looks really good with the lights off and the flashlight under it's face, so to speak.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
yeah you've definitly done a nice job of setting it up for a night scene, just one other thing I noticed this morning is the alpha planes on the trees dont look very cleen it looks like you painted the alphachannel with an airbrush, but im sure you're aware of them, you could probably get away them being all modeled.

I think the bricks need a sharper normalmap, Id suggest projecting it from a high poly model and give it some variation, I imagine you're going to be doing alot of projecting anyway with the scrolling ornaments.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
The bricks did get projected from geom, but the bevels need to be tighter, also got pulled into a sculpter and blurred them with a smooth brush while stamping, just playing around.

The alphas on the trees are a lot sharper than that, but they get downsampled at distance so they turn blurry- for these, the geom is probably enough, but that won't work for the pines.

dropped a new skybox and starting to test ground work:

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thats looking very nice for a test, do you think you could get the red light to reflect down along the road? I wonder if you could somehow create the illusion of anisotropic reflection.
which of those trees are modelled and which are in the background. can you show some wires of that shot?
looking good man

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
thanks for the encouragement! working on this thing feels dead slow sometimes. I don't think there's any modeled trees in that frame, just skybox. I'll post some more pics tomorrow when I get back to my PC.



I'm definitely excited about the ground stuff, i think I can get some very megatexture looking effects foregoing the per-pixel lighting.

The reflections across the icier, packed down parts of the path would be cool. I saw ATI's 'Toyshop' demo at Siggraph last year and it was bananas with that stuff. I wish I had more time to get into the shader programming, but maybe i can fake it somehow.

post.author: parsonsbear
Bo$bevok
post.body: cool

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
its a nice model but is that screen only showing the normal map? have you worked on the other maps too?

I can tell its not finished but, what is it? is it a giant spotlight? part of a telescope?

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
Yep- just normalmap (actually some parts don't even have that, or a faint white/grey grid for uv). It's a telescope, but a newer/smaller design than the others I'm working on. I had to put a screen up just so i could call it a night on the thing. It's been a, uh, learning experience. It looks very different ingame from the modeling app. Texture resolution is killing me too- I want to put lots of details into models, but a too high res bumpmap often gets blurry when viewed from far away, and compressed/jaggy looking when close up.

I'm going to make another pass at it soon, but i may put up a detailed list of these issues to try and get some help on it.

post.author: parsonsbear
mikebart
post.body:
Thats so cool , nice attention to detail and its such a great idea, I can really see why you chose this for a subject now.

I dont know what you've got planned for the sky but I think you could make it a bit more interesting, perhaps a higher resolution skybox? or maybe you could replace the skybox with an inverted sphere and have it slowly rotate on 2 axis
(did you mention earlier the stars were accurate?)

The telescope looks cool and the shadows make some interesting Silhouette's and the slide show's a great idea are you trying to make this educational?

Nice job man

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
thanks for checking in- not sure about educational, but certanly documentary.

the skybox is a pregenerated and correct for that lattitude and longitude, but the date is sometime ago. I've done tests with portalsky setups for drawing grids and stars, and will probably move over to that. I'm really into the batching topic going on right now, because the visible star count exceeds the max entity count, so if i'm generating accurate skies on the fly i need to take that into account. Either that or some kind of pixel shader for the stars.

post.author: Dinky
post.body:
efx wrote:
mikebart wrote:
how did you go about modeling those ornaments?


That's what I would like to know!


The ornaments look easy. The harder part that I see is that really neat patterned cylinder that's in the archway in the top area of the windows (the upside-down "U" shaped thing). Everything else looks pretty simple, but still very well done.

I always love it when people import models into Doom 3 for map editing, it's SO much better than those blocky brushes that the Radiant editor makes. But I have seen a lot of people make some really neat looking things with those brushes!

I still prefer neat imports .

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body: Looks good. Nice meshes.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
The patterened cylinder wasn't so bad, it's those curly leaf things that kill me. They're going to be problematic when I bake down to the low-poly, so I'll most likely have to redo them.

@mikebart- using modo, will try to work in some mudbox

The cylinder started out straight with 8 lengthwise edges and 22 segments. I pulled the lengthwise edges up and down to make the zig-zags in the segment edges. Then I beveled the zig-zags to make the cuts. I used the bend deformer to turn it into a half circle, then attached two straight segments to the ends to make a U. It's a sub-d model, so I can get away with fewer edges and still get round (at least until I'm done).

I didn't get the spacing quite right, so they look a litle busy- if i get the nerve to redo them I'll take some screens along the way.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body: Does anyone know what the max texture size d3 allows? I'm thinking of doing the whole wall with one texture- will 4096 texture sheets make it barf?

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
parsonsbear wrote:
The patterened cylinder wasn't so bad, it's those curly leaf things that kill me. They're going to be problematic when I bake down to the low-poly, so I'll most likely have to redo them.


I used alpha channelled geometry projected from the high poly models for the small details of the ornament on my low poly model just to get the shape of the edges without puting too many polys into it, but I think your column will project quite nicely as long as you fill the void.

post.body:
parsonsbear wrote:
Does anyone know what the max texture size d3 allows? I'm thinking of doing the whole wall with one texture- will 4096 texture sheets make it barf?


I think 1024x1024 is the max. It can also accept 256x256 and 512x512.

I'm not 100% sure though, as I've never tried above 1024x1024.

post.body:

post.author: The Happy Friar
post.body:
mikebart wrote:
ive gone up to 2048x2048, I thought it depends on your video/texture memory


yes. certain cards do a certain max res. I believe DX8 only goes up to 512x512. Here's a website that will show the info:

http://zp.lo3.wroc.pl/cdragan/wizard.php

post.body: wow that's a heck of a reference, thanks. I think I'm shooting for a new but not so fancy machine spec... maybe if it qualifies for d3 high quality that's cool- min 256 vram? I figure by the time I finish this d3 will be gpl and everyone will have a better machine than my laptop.

The cylinder started out straight with 8 lengthwise edges and 22 segments. I pulled the lengthwise edges up and down to make the zig-zags in the segment edges. Then I beveled the zig-zags to make the cuts. I used the bend deformer to turn it into a half circle, then attached two straight segments to the ends to make a U. It's a sub-d model, so I can get away with fewer edges and still get round (at least until I'm done).

I didn't get the spacing quite right, so they look a litle busy- if i get the nerve to redo them I'll take some screens along the way.

post.author: mikebart
post.body: looks great! , cant wait to see more, what modeling app are you using and how did you go about modeling those ornaments?

post.author: efx
post.body:
mikebart wrote:
how did you go about modeling those ornaments?


That's what I would like to know!

post.author: Dinky
post.body:
efx wrote:
mikebart wrote:
how did you go about modeling those ornaments?


That's what I would like to know!


The ornaments look easy. The harder part that I see is that really neat patterned cylinder that's in the archway in the top area of the windows (the upside-down "U" shaped thing). Everything else looks pretty simple, but still very well done.

I always love it when people import models into Doom 3 for map editing, it's SO much better than those blocky brushes that the Radiant editor makes. But I have seen a lot of people make some really neat looking things with those brushes!

I still prefer neat imports .

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body: Looks good. Nice meshes.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
The patterened cylinder wasn't so bad, it's those curly leaf things that kill me. They're going to be problematic when I bake down to the low-poly, so I'll most likely have to redo them.

@mikebart- using modo, will try to work in some mudbox

The cylinder started out straight with 8 lengthwise edges and 22 segments. I pulled the lengthwise edges up and down to make the zig-zags in the segment edges. Then I beveled the zig-zags to make the cuts. I used the bend deformer to turn it into a half circle, then attached two straight segments to the ends to make a U. It's a sub-d model, so I can get away with fewer edges and still get round (at least until I'm done).

I didn't get the spacing quite right, so they look a litle busy- if i get the nerve to redo them I'll take some screens along the way.

post.body:
did this exhaust vent on the back of the southbuilding yesterday, needs something to make it 'stick' to the wall, like a scumshadow decal:

[/url]

post.author: Kristus
post.body: Just put a metal collar on it.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body: Does anyone know what the max texture size d3 allows? I'm thinking of doing the whole wall with one texture- will 4096 texture sheets make it barf?

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
parsonsbear wrote:
The patterened cylinder wasn't so bad, it's those curly leaf things that kill me. They're going to be problematic when I bake down to the low-poly, so I'll most likely have to redo them.


I used alpha channelled geometry projected from the high poly models for the small details of the ornament on my low poly model just to get the shape of the edges without puting too many polys into it, but I think your column will project quite nicely as long as you fill the void.

post.author: Dinky
post.body:
parsonsbear wrote:
Does anyone know what the max texture size d3 allows? I'm thinking of doing the whole wall with one texture- will 4096 texture sheets make it barf?


I think 1024x1024 is the max. It can also accept 256x256 and 512x512.

I'm not 100% sure though, as I've never tried above 1024x1024.

post.author: The Happy Friar
post.body:
i've never tried above 1024x768 either.

just make sure the wall isn't one large brush though. Break it up in to several.

post.author: Dinky
post.body:
The Happy Friar wrote:
i've never tried above 1024x768 either.


Don't you mean 1024x1024??

The Happy Friar wrote:
just make sure the wall isn't one large brush though. Break it up in to several.


That's a good idea.

mikebart wrote:

post.author: Dinky
post.body:
efx wrote:
mikebart wrote:
how did you go about modeling those ornaments?


That's what I would like to know!


The ornaments look easy. The harder part that I see is that really neat patterned cylinder that's in the archway in the top area of the windows (the upside-down "U" shaped thing). Everything else looks pretty simple, but still very well done.

I always love it when people import models into Doom 3 for map editing, it's SO much better than those blocky brushes that the Radiant editor makes. But I have seen a lot of people make some really neat looking things with those brushes!

I still prefer neat imports .

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body: Looks good. Nice meshes.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
The patterened cylinder wasn't so bad, it's those curly leaf things that kill me. They're going to be problematic when I bake down to the low-poly, so I'll most likely have to redo them.

@mikebart- using modo, will try to work in some mudbox

The cylinder started out straight with 8 lengthwise edges and 22 segments. I pulled the lengthwise edges up and down to make the zig-zags in the segment edges. Then I beveled the zig-zags to make the cuts. I used the bend deformer to turn it into a half circle, then attached two straight segments to the ends to make a U. It's a sub-d model, so I can get away with fewer edges and still get round (at least until I'm done).

I didn't get the spacing quite right, so they look a litle busy- if i get the nerve to redo them I'll take some screens along the way.

post.body: Just put a metal collar on it.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body: Does anyone know what the max texture size d3 allows? I'm thinking of doing the whole wall with one texture- will 4096 texture sheets make it barf?

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
parsonsbear wrote:
The patterened cylinder wasn't so bad, it's those curly leaf things that kill me. They're going to be problematic when I bake down to the low-poly, so I'll most likely have to redo them.


I used alpha channelled geometry projected from the high poly models for the small details of the ornament on my low poly model just to get the shape of the edges without puting too many polys into it, but I think your column will project quite nicely as long as you fill the void.

post.author: Dinky
post.body:
parsonsbear wrote:
Does anyone know what the max texture size d3 allows? I'm thinking of doing the whole wall with one texture- will 4096 texture sheets make it barf?


I think 1024x1024 is the max. It can also accept 256x256 and 512x512.

I'm not 100% sure though, as I've never tried above 1024x1024.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
parsonsbear wrote:
The patterened cylinder wasn't so bad, it's those curly leaf things that kill me. They're going to be problematic when I bake down to the low-poly, so I'll most likely have to redo them.


I used alpha channelled geometry projected from the high poly models for the small details of the ornament on my low poly model just to get the shape of the edges without puting too many polys into it, but I think your column will project quite nicely as long as you fill the void.

post.author: Dinky
post.body:
parsonsbear wrote:
Does anyone know what the max texture size d3 allows? I'm thinking of doing the whole wall with one texture- will 4096 texture sheets make it barf?


I think 1024x1024 is the max. It can also accept 256x256 and 512x512.

I'm not 100% sure though, as I've never tried above 1024x1024.

post.author: The Happy Friar
post.body:
i've never tried above 1024x768 either.

just make sure the wall isn't one large brush though. Break it up in to several.

post.body:

i've never tried above 1024x768 either.


Don't you mean 1024x1024??

The Happy Friar wrote:
just make sure the wall isn't one large brush though. Break it up in to several.


That's a good idea.

post.author: Dinky
post.body:
efx wrote:
mikebart wrote:
how did you go about modeling those ornaments?


That's what I would like to know!


The ornaments look easy. The harder part that I see is that really neat patterned cylinder that's in the archway in the top area of the windows (the upside-down "U" shaped thing). Everything else looks pretty simple, but still very well done.

I always love it when people import models into Doom 3 for map editing, it's SO much better than those blocky brushes that the Radiant editor makes. But I have seen a lot of people make some really neat looking things with those brushes!

I still prefer neat imports .

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body: Looks good. Nice meshes.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
The patterened cylinder wasn't so bad, it's those curly leaf things that kill me. They're going to be problematic when I bake down to the low-poly, so I'll most likely have to redo them.

@mikebart- using modo, will try to work in some mudbox

The cylinder started out straight with 8 lengthwise edges and 22 segments. I pulled the lengthwise edges up and down to make the zig-zags in the segment edges. Then I beveled the zig-zags to make the cuts. I used the bend deformer to turn it into a half circle, then attached two straight segments to the ends to make a U. It's a sub-d model, so I can get away with fewer edges and still get round (at least until I'm done).

I didn't get the spacing quite right, so they look a litle busy- if i get the nerve to redo them I'll take some screens along the way.

post.body:
looks good, how did you go about making the snow?
If you're doing this for etqw the textures are probably good but if its for a portfolio project or something i'd crank the resolution up a bit.

where does the ornamental scrolling fit into those shots? is it a seperate building?
_________________
Tutorial; Baking Multiple Maps in 3dsmax8.

post.date: Posted: Thu Mar 15, 2007 4:34 pm Post subject:
post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
The snow is two particle effects, one custom (the falling dots) and the drifting is a recolored id particle.

The ornamental stuff is the main building, this is kinda like the shed. I'm doing this one first to get a feel for texture scale and in-game proportions. I can iterate over this one a lot quicker than the heavy one. The tower wall texture is giving me trouble- It's like a stucco, and the map is a lot more detailed than that, but it gets all blurry as you move away from it. I'll post images of the texture and some screens to illustrate later. The bricks are really tiling poorly, need better bump.

At this point I'm probably going to start over on it to fix a lot of the mistakes I made along the way. I have a better idea of how i need to deviate from reference to get the most out of the engine, as d3 is going to require a specific look- umm, dark. Not that it can't do lit, but it just looks really good with the lights off and the flashlight under it's face, so to speak.

post.date: Posted: Fri Mar 16, 2007 12:18 am Post subject:
post.author: mikebart
post.body:
yeah you've definitly done a nice job of setting it up for a night scene, just one other thing I noticed this morning is the alpha planes on the trees dont look very cleen it looks like you painted the alphachannel with an airbrush, but im sure you're aware of them, you could probably get away them being all modeled.

I think the bricks need a sharper normalmap, Id suggest projecting it from a high poly model and give it some variation, I imagine you're going to be doing alot of projecting anyway with the scrolling ornaments.
_________________
Tutorial; Baking Multiple Maps in 3dsmax8.

post.date: Posted: Fri Mar 16, 2007 1:25 am Post subject:
post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
The bricks did get projected from geom, but the bevels need to be tighter, also got pulled into a sculpter and blurred them with a smooth brush while stamping, just playing around.

The alphas on the trees are a lot sharper than that, but they get downsampled at distance so they turn blurry- for these, the geom is probably enough, but that won't work for the pines.

dropped a new skybox and starting to test ground work:

looking good man

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
thanks for the encouragement! working on this thing feels dead slow sometimes. I don't think there's any modeled trees in that frame, just skybox. I'll post some more pics tomorrow when I get back to my PC.



I'm definitely excited about the ground stuff, i think I can get some very megatexture looking effects foregoing the per-pixel lighting.

The reflections across the icier, packed down parts of the path would be cool. I saw ATI's 'Toyshop' demo at Siggraph last year and it was bananas with that stuff. I wish I had more time to get into the shader programming, but maybe i can fake it somehow.

	background-color: #D1D7DC; border: #FFFFFF; border-style: solid;
}

th.thHead,td.catHead { font-size: 12px; border-width: 1px 1px 0px 1px; }
th.thSides,td.catSides,td.spaceRow	 { border-width: 0px 1px 0px 1px; }
th.thRight,td.catRight,td.row3Right	 { border-width: 0px 1px 0px 0px; }
th.thLeft,td.catLeft	  { border-width: 0px 0px 0px 1px; }
th.thBottom,td.catBottom  { border-width: 0px 1px 1px 1px; }
th.thTop	 { border-width: 1px 0px 0px 0px; }
th.thCornerL { border-width: 1px 0px 0px 1px; }
th.thCornerR { border-width: 1px 1px 0px 0px; }

/* The largest text used in the index page title and toptic title etc. */
.maintitle	{
	font-weight: bold; font-size: 22px; font-family: "Trebuchet MS",Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
	text-decoration: none; line-height : 120%; color : #000000;
}

/* General text */
.gen { font-size : 12px; }
.genmed { font-size : 11px; }
.gensmall { font-size : 10px; }
.gen,.genmed,.gensmall { color : #000000; }
a.gen,a.genmed,a.gensmall { color: #006699; text-decoration: none; }
a.gen:hover,a.genmed:hover,a.gensmall:hover	{ color: #DD6900; text-decoration: underline; }

/* The register, login, search etc links at the top of the page */
.mainmenu		{ font-size : 11px; color : #000000 }
a.mainmenu		{ text-decoration: none; color : #006699;  }
a.mainmenu:hover{ text-decoration: underline; color : #DD6900; }

/* Forum category titles */
.cattitle		{ font-weight: bold; font-size: 12px ; letter-spacing: 1px; color : #006699}
a.cattitle		{ text-decoration: none; color : #006699; }
a.cattitle:hover{ text-decoration: underline; }

/* Forum title: Text and link to the forums used in: index.php */
.forumlink		{ font-weight: bold; font-size: 12px; color : #006699; }
a.forumlink 	{ text-decoration: none; color : #006699; }
a.forumlink:hover{ text-decoration: underline; color : #DD6900; }

/* Used for the navigation text, (Page 1,2,3 etc) and the navigation bar when in a forum */
.nav			{ font-weight: bold; font-size: 11px; color : #000000;}
a.nav			{ text-decoration: none; color : #006699; }
a.nav:hover		{ text-decoration: underline; }

/* titles for the topics: could specify viewed link colour too */
.topictitle,h1,h2	{ font-weight: bold; font-size: 11px; color : #000000; }
a.topictitle:link   { text-decoration: none; color : #006699; }
a.topictitle:visited { text-decoration: none; color : #5493B4; }
a.topictitle:hover	{ text-decoration: underline; color : #DD6900; }

/* Name of poster in viewmsg.php and viewtopic.php and other places */
.name			{ font-size : 11px; color : #000000;}

/* Location, number of posts, post date etc */
.postdetails		{ font-size : 10px; color : #000000; }

/* The content of the posts (body of text) */
.postbody { font-size : 12px; line-height: 18px}
a.postlink:link	{ text-decoration: none; color : #006699 }
a.postlink:visited { text-decoration: none; color : #5493B4; }
a.postlink:hover { text-decoration: underline; color : #DD6900}

/* Quote & Code blocks */
.code {
	font-family: Courier, 'Courier New', sans-serif; font-size: 11px; color: #006600;
	background-color: #FAFAFA; border: #D1D7DC; border-style: solid;
	border-left-width: 1px; border-top-width: 1px; border-right-width: 1px; border-bottom-width: 1px
}

.quote {
	font-family: Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 11px; color: #444444; line-height: 125%;
	background-color: #FAFAFA; border: #D1D7DC; border-style: solid;
	border-left-width: 1px; border-top-width: 1px; border-right-width: 1px; border-bottom-width: 1px
}

/* Copyright and bottom info */
.copyright		{ font-size: 10px; font-family: Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; color: #444444; letter-spacing: -1px;}
a.copyright		{ color: #444444; text-decoration: none;}
a.copyright:hover { color: #000000; text-decoration: underline;}

/* Form elements */
input,textarea, select {
	color : #000000;
	font: normal 11px Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
	border-color : #000000;
}

/* The text input fields background colour */
input.post, textarea.post, select {
	background-color : #FFFFFF;
}

input { text-indent : 2px; }

/* The buttons used for bbCode styling in message post */
input.button {
	background-color : #EFEFEF;
	color : #000000;
	font-size: 11px; font-family: Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}

/* The main submit button option */
input.mainoption {
	background-color : #FAFAFA;
	font-weight : bold;
}

/* None-bold submit button */
input.liteoption {
	background-color : #FAFAFA;
	font-weight : normal;
}

/* This is the line in the posting page which shows the rollover
  help line. This is actually a text box, but if set to be the same
  colour as the background no one will know ;)
*/
.helpline { background-color: #DEE3E7; border-style: none; }

/* Import the fancy styles for IE only (NS4.x doesn't use the @import function) */
@import url("https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/formIE.css");
-->
]] ></style>

//<![CDATA[

var curYear = -1;
var curMonth = -1;
var yearCount = 18;
var firstYear = 1996;
var imgWidth = 475;
var yearImgWidth = 25;
var monthImgWidth = 2;
var trackerVal = "none";
var displayDay = "9";
var displayMonth = "May";
var displayYear = "2007";
var prettyMonths = ["Jan","Feb","Mar","Apr","May","Jun","Jul","Aug","Sep","Oct","Nov","Dec"];

function showTrackers(val) {
	if(val == trackerVal) {
		return;
	}
	if(val == "inline") {
		document.getElementById("displayYearEl").style.color = "#ec008c";
		document.getElementById("displayMonthEl").style.color = "#ec008c";
		document.getElementById("displayDayEl").style.color = "#ec008c";		
	} else {
		document.getElementById("displayYearEl").innerHTML = displayYear;
		document.getElementById("displayYearEl").style.color = "#ff0";
		document.getElementById("displayMonthEl").innerHTML = displayMonth;
		document.getElementById("displayMonthEl").style.color = "#ff0";
		document.getElementById("displayDayEl").innerHTML = displayDay;
		document.getElementById("displayDayEl").style.color = "#ff0";
	}
   document.getElementById("wbMouseTrackYearImg").style.display = val;
   document.getElementById("wbMouseTrackMonthImg").style.display = val;
   trackerVal = val;
}
function getElementX2(obj) {
	var thing = jQuery(obj);
	if((thing == undefined) 
			|| (typeof thing == "undefined") 
			|| (typeof thing.offset == "undefined")) {
		return getElementX(obj);
	}
	return Math.round(thing.offset().left);
}
function trackMouseMove(event,element) {

   var eventX = getEventX(event);
   var elementX = getElementX2(element);
   var xOff = eventX - elementX;
	if(xOff < 0) {
		xOff = 0;
	} else if(xOff > imgWidth) {
		xOff = imgWidth;
	}
   var monthOff = xOff % yearImgWidth;

   var year = Math.floor(xOff / yearImgWidth);
	var yearStart = year * yearImgWidth;
   var monthOfYear = Math.floor(monthOff / monthImgWidth);
   if(monthOfYear > 11) {
       monthOfYear = 11;
   }
   // 1 extra border pixel at the left edge of the year:
   var month = (year * 12) + monthOfYear;
   var day = 1;
	if(monthOff % 2 == 1) {
		day = 15;
	}
	var dateString = 
		zeroPad(year + firstYear) + 
		zeroPad(monthOfYear+1,2) +
		zeroPad(day,2) + "000000";

	var monthString = prettyMonths[monthOfYear];
	document.getElementById("displayYearEl").innerHTML = year + 1996;
	document.getElementById("displayMonthEl").innerHTML = monthString;
	// looks too jarring when it changes..
	//document.getElementById("displayDayEl").innerHTML = zeroPad(day,2);

	var url = wbPrefix + dateString + '/' +  wbCurrentUrl;
	document.getElementById('wm-graph-anchor').href = url;

   //document.getElementById("wmtbURL").value="evX("+eventX+") elX("+elementX+") xO("+xOff+") y("+year+") m("+month+") monthOff("+monthOff+") DS("+dateString+") Moy("+monthOfYear+") ms("+monthString+")";
   if(curYear != year) {
       var yrOff = year * yearImgWidth;
       document.getElementById("wbMouseTrackYearImg").style.left = yrOff + "px";
       curYear = year;
   }
   if(curMonth != month) {
       var mtOff = year + (month * monthImgWidth) + 1;
       document.getElementById("wbMouseTrackMonthImg").style.left = mtOff + "px";
       curMonth = month;
   }
}
//]]]] ><![CDATA[>

			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><hr/></td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><span class="postbody">wow that's a heck of a reference, thanks. I think I'm shooting for a new but not so fancy machine spec... maybe if it qualifies for d3 high quality that's cool- min 256 vram? I figure by the time I finish this d3 will be gpl and everyone will have a better machine than my laptop.</span><span class="gensmall"/></td>
			</tr></table></td>

	</tr><tr><td width="150" align="left" valign="top" class="row1"><span class="name"><a name="173076"/><b>mikebart</b></span><br/><span class="postdetails">fired 300 rounds<br/><br/><br/>Joined: 13 Sep 2004<br/>Posts: 304<br/>Location: Melbourne Australia</span><br/></td>
		<td class="row1" width="100%" height="28" valign="top"><table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"><tr><td width="100%"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?p=173076&sid=93c46254bc00f3517943ba83fb6b9b34#173076"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/icon_minipost.gif" width="12" height="9" alt="Post" title="Post" border="0"/></a><span class="postdetails">Posted: Thu Mar 15, 2007 9:56 am<span class="gen"></span> Post subject: </span></td>
				<td valign="top" nowrap="nowrap"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/posting.php?mode=quote&p=173076&sid=93c46254bc00f3517943ba83fb6b9b34"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_quote.gif" alt="Reply with quote" title="Reply with quote" border="0"/></a>   </td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><hr/></td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><span class="postbody">looks good, how did you go about making the snow?
<br/>
If you're doing this for etqw the textures are probably good but if its for a portfolio project or something i'd crank the resolution up a bit.
<br/><br/>
where does the ornamental scrolling fit into those shots? is it a seperate building?<br/>_________________<br/><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?p=160978#160978" target="_blank" class="postlink">Tutorial; Baking Multiple Maps in 3dsmax8. </a></span><span class="gensmall"/></td>
			</tr></table></td>
	</tr><tr><td class="row1" width="150" align="left" valign="middle"><span class="nav"><a href="viewtopic.php?p=172653#top" class="nav">Back to top</a></span></td>
		<td class="row1" width="100%" height="28" valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap"><table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" height="18" width="18"><tr><td valign="middle" nowrap="nowrap"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/profile.php?mode=viewprofile&u=5145&sid=93c46254bc00f3517943ba83fb6b9b34"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_profile.gif" alt="View user's profile" title="View user's profile" border="0"/></a> <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/privmsg.php?mode=post&u=5145&sid=93c46254bc00f3517943ba83fb6b9b34"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_pm.gif" alt="Send private message" title="Send private message" border="0"/></a>     <script language="JavaScript" type="text/javascript"><![CDATA[<!--

	if ( navigator.userAgent.toLowerCase().indexOf('mozilla') != -1 && navigator.userAgent.indexOf('5.') == -1 && navigator.userAgent.indexOf('6.') == -1 )

	else
		document.write(']] ></script></td><td></td><td valign="top" nowrap="nowrap"><div style="position:relative"><div style="position:absolute"/><div style="position:absolute;left:3px;top:-1px"/></div>');

	</tr><tr><td class="spaceRow" colspan="2" height="1"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/spacer.gif" alt="" width="1" height="1"/></td>
	</tr><tr><td width="150" align="left" valign="top" class="row2"><span class="name"><a name="173103"/><b>parsonsbear</b></span><br/><span class="postdetails">missed 400 shots<br/><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/images/avatars/upload/5309092814365b0dc6944a.gif" alt="" border="0"/><br/><br/>Joined: 06 Jan 2005<br/>Posts: 427<br/></span><br/></td>
		<td class="row2" width="100%" height="28" valign="top"><table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"><tr><td width="100%"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?p=173103&sid=93c46254bc00f3517943ba83fb6b9b34#173103"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/icon_minipost.gif" width="12" height="9" alt="Post" title="Post" border="0"/></a><span class="postdetails">Posted: Thu Mar 15, 2007 4:34 pm<span class="gen"></span> Post subject: </span></td>
				<td valign="top" nowrap="nowrap"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/posting.php?mode=quote&p=173103&sid=93c46254bc00f3517943ba83fb6b9b34"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_quote.gif" alt="Reply with quote" title="Reply with quote" border="0"/></a>   </td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><hr/></td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><span class="postbody">The snow is two particle effects, one custom (the falling dots) and the drifting is a recolored id particle.
<br/><br/>
The ornamental stuff is the main building, this is kinda like the shed. I'm doing this one first to get a feel for texture scale and in-game proportions. I can iterate over this one a lot quicker than the heavy one. The tower wall texture is giving me trouble- It's like a stucco, and the map is a lot more detailed than that, but it gets all blurry as you move away from it. I'll post images of the texture and some screens to illustrate later. The bricks are really tiling poorly, need better bump.
<br/><br/>
At this point I'm probably going to start over on it to fix a lot of the mistakes I made along the way. I have a better idea of how i need to deviate from reference to get the most out of the engine, as d3 is going to require a specific look- umm, dark. Not that it can't do lit, but it just looks really good with the lights off and the flashlight under it's face, so to speak.</span><span class="gensmall"/></td>
			</tr></table></td>
	</tr><tr><td class="row2" width="150" align="left" valign="middle"><span class="nav"><a href="viewtopic.php?p=172653#top" class="nav">Back to top</a></span></td>
		<td class="row2" width="100%" height="28" valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap"><table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" height="18" width="18"><tr><td valign="middle" nowrap="nowrap"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/profile.php?mode=viewprofile&u=12142&sid=93c46254bc00f3517943ba83fb6b9b34"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_profile.gif" alt="View user's profile" title="View user's profile" border="0"/></a> <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/privmsg.php?mode=post&u=12142&sid=93c46254bc00f3517943ba83fb6b9b34"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_pm.gif" alt="Send private message" title="Send private message" border="0"/></a>   <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/aim:goim?screenname=cptincog&message=Hello+Are+you+there?"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_aim.gif" alt="AIM Address" title="AIM Address" border="0"/></a>  <script language="JavaScript" type="text/javascript"><![CDATA[<!--

	</tr><tr><td class="spaceRow" colspan="2" height="1"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/spacer.gif" alt="" width="1" height="1"/></td>
	</tr><tr><td width="150" align="left" valign="top" class="row1"><span class="name"><a name="173143"/><b>mikebart</b></span><br/><span class="postdetails">fired 300 rounds<br/><br/><br/>Joined: 13 Sep 2004<br/>Posts: 304<br/>Location: Melbourne Australia</span><br/></td>
		<td class="row1" width="100%" height="28" valign="top"><table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"><tr><td width="100%"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?p=173143&sid=93c46254bc00f3517943ba83fb6b9b34#173143"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/icon_minipost.gif" width="12" height="9" alt="Post" title="Post" border="0"/></a><span class="postdetails">Posted: Fri Mar 16, 2007 12:18 am<span class="gen"></span> Post subject: </span></td>
				<td valign="top" nowrap="nowrap"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/posting.php?mode=quote&p=173143&sid=93c46254bc00f3517943ba83fb6b9b34"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_quote.gif" alt="Reply with quote" title="Reply with quote" border="0"/></a>   </td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><hr/></td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><span class="postbody">yeah you've definitly done a nice job of setting it up for a night scene, just one other thing I noticed this morning is the alpha planes on the trees dont look very cleen it looks like you painted the alphachannel with an airbrush, but im sure you're aware of them, you could probably get away them being all modeled.
<br/><br/>
I think the bricks need a sharper normalmap, Id suggest projecting it from a high poly model and give it some variation, I imagine you're going to be doing alot of projecting anyway with the scrolling ornaments.<br/>_________________<br/><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?p=160978#160978" target="_blank" class="postlink">Tutorial; Baking Multiple Maps in 3dsmax8. </a></span><span class="gensmall"/></td>
			</tr></table></td>
	</tr><tr><td class="row1" width="150" align="left" valign="middle"><span class="nav"><a href="viewtopic.php?p=172653#top" class="nav">Back to top</a></span></td>
		<td class="row1" width="100%" height="28" valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap"><table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" height="18" width="18"><tr><td valign="middle" nowrap="nowrap"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/profile.php?mode=viewprofile&u=5145&sid=93c46254bc00f3517943ba83fb6b9b34"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_profile.gif" alt="View user's profile" title="View user's profile" border="0"/></a> <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/privmsg.php?mode=post&u=5145&sid=93c46254bc00f3517943ba83fb6b9b34"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_pm.gif" alt="Send private message" title="Send private message" border="0"/></a>     <script language="JavaScript" type="text/javascript"><![CDATA[<!--

	if ( navigator.userAgent.toLowerCase().indexOf('mozilla') != -1 && navigator.userAgent.indexOf('5.') == -1 && navigator.userAgent.indexOf('6.') == -1 )
		document.write(' ');
	else
		document.write(']] ></script></td><td></td><td valign="top" nowrap="nowrap"><div style="position:relative"><div style="position:absolute"/><div style="position:absolute;left:3px;top:-1px"/></div>');

				//--><noscript/></td>
			</tr></table></td>
	</tr><tr><td class="spaceRow" colspan="2" height="1"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/spacer.gif" alt="" width="1" height="1"/></td>
	</tr><tr><td width="150" align="left" valign="top" class="row2"><span class="name"><a name="173153"/><b>parsonsbear</b></span><br/><span class="postdetails">missed 400 shots<br/><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/images/avatars/upload/5309092814365b0dc6944a.gif" alt="" border="0"/><br/><br/>Joined: 06 Jan 2005<br/>Posts: 427<br/></span><br/></td>
		<td class="row2" width="100%" height="28" valign="top"><table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"><tr><td width="100%"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?p=173153&sid=93c46254bc00f3517943ba83fb6b9b34#173153"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/icon_minipost.gif" width="12" height="9" alt="Post" title="Post" border="0"/></a><span class="postdetails">Posted: Fri Mar 16, 2007 1:25 am<span class="gen"></span> Post subject: </span></td>
				<td valign="top" nowrap="nowrap"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/posting.php?mode=quote&p=173153&sid=93c46254bc00f3517943ba83fb6b9b34"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_quote.gif" alt="Reply with quote" title="Reply with quote" border="0"/></a>   </td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><hr/></td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><span class="postbody">The bricks did get projected from geom, but the bevels need to be tighter, also got pulled into a sculpter and blurred them with a smooth brush while stamping, just playing around. 
<br/><br/>
The alphas on the trees are a lot sharper than that, but they get downsampled at distance so they turn blurry- for these, the geom is probably enough, but that won't work for the pines.
<br/><br/>
dropped a new skybox and starting to test ground work:
<br/><br/><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://a.parsons.edu/~evan/yerkes/snowtest.jpg" border="0"/></span><span class="gensmall"/></td>
			</tr></table></td>
	</tr><tr><td class="row2" width="150" align="left" valign="middle"><span class="nav"><a href="viewtopic.php?p=172653#top" class="nav">Back to top</a></span></td>

			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><hr/></td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><span class="postbody">thats looking very nice for a test, do you think you could get the red light to reflect down along the road? I wonder if you could somehow create the illusion of anisotropic reflection.

				<td valign="top" nowrap="nowrap"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/posting.php?mode=quote&p=173176&sid=93c46254bc00f3517943ba83fb6b9b34"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_quote.gif" alt="Reply with quote" title="Reply with quote" border="0"/></a>   </td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><hr/></td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><span class="postbody">thanks for the encouragement! working on this thing feels dead slow sometimes. I don't think there's any modeled trees in that frame, just skybox. I'll post some more pics tomorrow when I get back to my PC.
<br/><br/><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://a.parsons.edu/~evan/yerkes/nightsky_treeLayer.jpg" border="0"/><br/><br/>
I'm definitely excited about the ground stuff, i think I can get some very megatexture looking effects foregoing the per-pixel lighting.
<br/><br/>
The reflections across the icier, packed down parts of the path would be cool. I saw ATI's 'Toyshop' demo at Siggraph last year and it was bananas with that stuff. I wish I had more time to get into the shader programming, but maybe i can fake it somehow.</span><span class="gensmall"/></td>

Yeah, I've played around with using the photosource to generate heightmaps, as well as drawing them out in mudbox (i'm not very good at sculpting though) I think as I do more ornament I'll get a better feel for what's worth modeling.

post.date: Posted: Sat Mar 10, 2007 4:26 pm Post subject:
post.author: The Happy Friar
post.body:
mikebart wrote:
ive gone up to 2048x2048, I thought it depends on your video/texture memory


yes. certain cards do a certain max res. I believe DX8 only goes up to 512x512. Here's a website that will show the info:

http://zp.lo3.wroc.pl/cdragan/wizard.php

post.body: wow that's a heck of a reference, thanks. I think I'm shooting for a new but not so fancy machine spec... maybe if it qualifies for d3 high quality that's cool- min 256 vram? I figure by the time I finish this d3 will be gpl and everyone will have a better machine than my laptop.

post.date: Posted: Thu Mar 15, 2007 3:15 am Post subject:
post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
new shots:







and some bad weather:

post.date: Posted: Thu Mar 15, 2007 9:56 am Post subject:
post.author: mikebart
post.body:
looks good, how did you go about making the snow?
If you're doing this for etqw the textures are probably good but if its for a portfolio project or something i'd crank the resolution up a bit.

where does the ornamental scrolling fit into those shots? is it a seperate building?
_________________
Tutorial; Baking Multiple Maps in 3dsmax8.

post.date: Posted: Thu Mar 15, 2007 4:34 pm Post subject:
post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
The snow is two particle effects, one custom (the falling dots) and the drifting is a recolored id particle.

The ornamental stuff is the main building, this is kinda like the shed. I'm doing this one first to get a feel for texture scale and in-game proportions. I can iterate over this one a lot quicker than the heavy one. The tower wall texture is giving me trouble- It's like a stucco, and the map is a lot more detailed than that, but it gets all blurry as you move away from it. I'll post images of the texture and some screens to illustrate later. The bricks are really tiling poorly, need better bump.

At this point I'm probably going to start over on it to fix a lot of the mistakes I made along the way. I have a better idea of how i need to deviate from reference to get the most out of the engine, as d3 is going to require a specific look- umm, dark. Not that it can't do lit, but it just looks really good with the lights off and the flashlight under it's face, so to speak.

post.date: Posted: Fri Mar 16, 2007 12:18 am Post subject:
post.author: mikebart
post.body:
yeah you've definitly done a nice job of setting it up for a night scene, just one other thing I noticed this morning is the alpha planes on the trees dont look very cleen it looks like you painted the alphachannel with an airbrush, but im sure you're aware of them, you could probably get away them being all modeled.

I think the bricks need a sharper normalmap, Id suggest projecting it from a high poly model and give it some variation, I imagine you're going to be doing alot of projecting anyway with the scrolling ornaments.
_________________
Tutorial; Baking Multiple Maps in 3dsmax8.

post.date: Posted: Fri Mar 16, 2007 1:25 am Post subject:
post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
The bricks did get projected from geom, but the bevels need to be tighter, also got pulled into a sculpter and blurred them with a smooth brush while stamping, just playing around.

The alphas on the trees are a lot sharper than that, but they get downsampled at distance so they turn blurry- for these, the geom is probably enough, but that won't work for the pines.

dropped a new skybox and starting to test ground work:

post.date: Posted: Fri Mar 16, 2007 3:30 am Post subject:
post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thats looking very nice for a test, do you think you could get the red light to reflect down along the road? I wonder if you could somehow create the illusion of anisotropic reflection.
which of those trees are modelled and which are in the background. can you show some wires of that shot?
looking good man
_________________
Tutorial; Baking Multiple Maps in 3dsmax8.

post.date: Posted: Fri Mar 16, 2007 6:27 am Post subject:
post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
thanks for the encouragement! working on this thing feels dead slow sometimes. I don't think there's any modeled trees in that frame, just skybox. I'll post some more pics tomorrow when I get back to my PC.



I'm definitely excited about the ground stuff, i think I can get some very megatexture looking effects foregoing the per-pixel lighting.

The reflections across the icier, packed down parts of the path would be cool. I saw ATI's 'Toyshop' demo at Siggraph last year and it was bananas with that stuff. I wish I had more time to get into the shader programming, but maybe i can fake it somehow.

post.date: Posted: Tue Mar 27, 2007 11:15 am Post subject:
post.author: parsonsbear

post.author: Bo$bevok
post.body: cool

post.author: mikebart

}

//<![CDATA[
var firstDate = 820454400000;
var lastDate = 1420070399999;
var wbPrefix = "/web/";
var wbCurrentUrl = "http:\/\/www.doom3world.org\/phpbb2\/viewtopic.php?p=172656";

var curYear = -1;
var curMonth = -1;
var yearCount = 18;
var firstYear = 1996;
var imgWidth = 475;
var yearImgWidth = 25;
var monthImgWidth = 2;
var trackerVal = "none";
var displayDay = "9";
var displayMonth = "May";
var displayYear = "2007";
var prettyMonths = ["Jan","Feb","Mar","Apr","May","Jun","Jul","Aug","Sep","Oct","Nov","Dec"];

function showTrackers(val) {
	if(val == trackerVal) {
		return;
	}
	if(val == "inline") {
		document.getElementById("displayYearEl").style.color = "#ec008c";
		document.getElementById("displayMonthEl").style.color = "#ec008c";
		document.getElementById("displayDayEl").style.color = "#ec008c";		
	} else {
		document.getElementById("displayYearEl").innerHTML = displayYear;
		document.getElementById("displayYearEl").style.color = "#ff0";
		document.getElementById("displayMonthEl").innerHTML = displayMonth;
		document.getElementById("displayMonthEl").style.color = "#ff0";
		document.getElementById("displayDayEl").innerHTML = displayDay;
		document.getElementById("displayDayEl").style.color = "#ff0";
	}
   document.getElementById("wbMouseTrackYearImg").style.display = val;
   document.getElementById("wbMouseTrackMonthImg").style.display = val;
   trackerVal = val;
}
function getElementX2(obj) {
	var thing = jQuery(obj);
	if((thing == undefined) 
			|| (typeof thing == "undefined") 
			|| (typeof thing.offset == "undefined")) {
		return getElementX(obj);
	}
	return Math.round(thing.offset().left);
}
function trackMouseMove(event,element) {

   var eventX = getEventX(event);
   var elementX = getElementX2(element);
   var xOff = eventX - elementX;
	if(xOff < 0) {
		xOff = 0;
	} else if(xOff > imgWidth) {
		xOff = imgWidth;
	}
   var monthOff = xOff % yearImgWidth;

   var year = Math.floor(xOff / yearImgWidth);
	var yearStart = year * yearImgWidth;
   var monthOfYear = Math.floor(monthOff / monthImgWidth);
   if(monthOfYear > 11) {
       monthOfYear = 11;
   }
   // 1 extra border pixel at the left edge of the year:
   var month = (year * 12) + monthOfYear;
   var day = 1;
	if(monthOff % 2 == 1) {
		day = 15;
	}
	var dateString = 
		zeroPad(year + firstYear) + 
		zeroPad(monthOfYear+1,2) +
		zeroPad(day,2) + "000000";

	var monthString = prettyMonths[monthOfYear];
	document.getElementById("displayYearEl").innerHTML = year + 1996;
	document.getElementById("displayMonthEl").innerHTML = monthString;
	// looks too jarring when it changes..
	//document.getElementById("displayDayEl").innerHTML = zeroPad(day,2);

	var url = wbPrefix + dateString + '/' +  wbCurrentUrl;
	document.getElementById('wm-graph-anchor').href = url;

   //document.getElementById("wmtbURL").value="evX("+eventX+") elX("+elementX+") xO("+xOff+") y("+year+") m("+month+") monthOff("+monthOff+") DS("+dateString+") Moy("+monthOfYear+") ms("+monthString+")";
   if(curYear != year) {
       var yrOff = year * yearImgWidth;
       document.getElementById("wbMouseTrackYearImg").style.left = yrOff + "px";
       curYear = year;
   }
   if(curMonth != month) {
       var mtOff = year + (month * monthImgWidth) + 1;
       document.getElementById("wbMouseTrackMonthImg").style.left = mtOff + "px";
       curMonth = month;
   }
}
//]]]] ><![CDATA[>
]] ></script><style type="text/css"><![CDATA[body{margin-top:0!important;padding-top:0!important;min-width:800px!important;}#wm-ipp a:hover{text-decoration:underline!important;}]] ></style><div id="wm-ipp" lang="en" class="__wb_banner_div" style="display:none; position:relative;padding:0 5px;min-height:70px;min-width:800px">

		<td class="row1" width="100%" height="28" valign="top"><table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"><tr><td width="100%"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?p=173076&sid=4bc0edd9d9a2a9d9ee3b657c402a4f16#173076"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/icon_minipost.gif" width="12" height="9" alt="Post" title="Post" border="0"/></a><span class="postdetails">Posted: Thu Mar 15, 2007 9:56 am<span class="gen"></span> Post subject: </span></td>
				<td valign="top" nowrap="nowrap"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/posting.php?mode=quote&p=173076&sid=4bc0edd9d9a2a9d9ee3b657c402a4f16"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_quote.gif" alt="Reply with quote" title="Reply with quote" border="0"/></a>   </td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><hr/></td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><span class="postbody">looks good, how did you go about making the snow?
<br/>
If you're doing this for etqw the textures are probably good but if its for a portfolio project or something i'd crank the resolution up a bit.
<br/><br/>
where does the ornamental scrolling fit into those shots? is it a seperate building?<br/>_________________<br/><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?p=160978#160978" target="_blank" class="postlink">Tutorial; Baking Multiple Maps in 3dsmax8. </a></span><span class="gensmall"/></td>
			</tr></table></td>
	</tr><tr><td class="row1" width="150" align="left" valign="middle"><span class="nav"><a href="viewtopic.php?p=172656#top" class="nav">Back to top</a></span></td>
		<td class="row1" width="100%" height="28" valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap"><table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" height="18" width="18"><tr><td valign="middle" nowrap="nowrap"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/profile.php?mode=viewprofile&u=5145&sid=4bc0edd9d9a2a9d9ee3b657c402a4f16"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_profile.gif" alt="View user's profile" title="View user's profile" border="0"/></a> <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/privmsg.php?mode=post&u=5145&sid=4bc0edd9d9a2a9d9ee3b657c402a4f16"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_pm.gif" alt="Send private message" title="Send private message" border="0"/></a>     <script language="JavaScript" type="text/javascript"><![CDATA[<!--

	else
		document.write(']] ></script></td><td></td><td valign="top" nowrap="nowrap"><div style="position:relative"><div style="position:absolute"/><div style="position:absolute;left:3px;top:-1px"/></div>');

	</tr><tr><td class="spaceRow" colspan="2" height="1"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/spacer.gif" alt="" width="1" height="1"/></td>
	</tr><tr><td width="150" align="left" valign="top" class="row2"><span class="name"><a name="173103"/><b>parsonsbear</b></span><br/><span class="postdetails">missed 400 shots<br/><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/images/avatars/upload/5309092814365b0dc6944a.gif" alt="" border="0"/><br/><br/>Joined: 06 Jan 2005<br/>Posts: 427<br/></span><br/></td>
		<td class="row2" width="100%" height="28" valign="top"><table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"><tr><td width="100%"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?p=173103&sid=4bc0edd9d9a2a9d9ee3b657c402a4f16#173103"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/icon_minipost.gif" width="12" height="9" alt="Post" title="Post" border="0"/></a><span class="postdetails">Posted: Thu Mar 15, 2007 4:34 pm<span class="gen"></span> Post subject: </span></td>
				<td valign="top" nowrap="nowrap"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/posting.php?mode=quote&p=173103&sid=4bc0edd9d9a2a9d9ee3b657c402a4f16"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_quote.gif" alt="Reply with quote" title="Reply with quote" border="0"/></a>   </td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><hr/></td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><span class="postbody">The snow is two particle effects, one custom (the falling dots) and the drifting is a recolored id particle.
<br/><br/>
The ornamental stuff is the main building, this is kinda like the shed. I'm doing this one first to get a feel for texture scale and in-game proportions. I can iterate over this one a lot quicker than the heavy one. The tower wall texture is giving me trouble- It's like a stucco, and the map is a lot more detailed than that, but it gets all blurry as you move away from it. I'll post images of the texture and some screens to illustrate later. The bricks are really tiling poorly, need better bump.
<br/><br/>
At this point I'm probably going to start over on it to fix a lot of the mistakes I made along the way. I have a better idea of how i need to deviate from reference to get the most out of the engine, as d3 is going to require a specific look- umm, dark. Not that it can't do lit, but it just looks really good with the lights off and the flashlight under it's face, so to speak.</span><span class="gensmall"/></td>
			</tr></table></td>
	</tr><tr><td class="row2" width="150" align="left" valign="middle"><span class="nav"><a href="viewtopic.php?p=172656#top" class="nav">Back to top</a></span></td>
		<td class="row2" width="100%" height="28" valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap"><table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" height="18" width="18"><tr><td valign="middle" nowrap="nowrap"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/profile.php?mode=viewprofile&u=12142&sid=4bc0edd9d9a2a9d9ee3b657c402a4f16"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_profile.gif" alt="View user's profile" title="View user's profile" border="0"/></a> <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/privmsg.php?mode=post&u=12142&sid=4bc0edd9d9a2a9d9ee3b657c402a4f16"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_pm.gif" alt="Send private message" title="Send private message" border="0"/></a>   <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/aim:goim?screenname=cptincog&message=Hello+Are+you+there?"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_aim.gif" alt="AIM Address" title="AIM Address" border="0"/></a>  <script language="JavaScript" type="text/javascript"><![CDATA[<!--

	</tr><tr><td class="spaceRow" colspan="2" height="1"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/spacer.gif" alt="" width="1" height="1"/></td>
	</tr><tr><td width="150" align="left" valign="top" class="row1"><span class="name"><a name="173143"/><b>mikebart</b></span><br/><span class="postdetails">fired 300 rounds<br/><br/><br/>Joined: 13 Sep 2004<br/>Posts: 304<br/>Location: Melbourne Australia</span><br/></td>
		<td class="row1" width="100%" height="28" valign="top"><table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"><tr><td width="100%"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?p=173143&sid=4bc0edd9d9a2a9d9ee3b657c402a4f16#173143"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/icon_minipost.gif" width="12" height="9" alt="Post" title="Post" border="0"/></a><span class="postdetails">Posted: Fri Mar 16, 2007 12:18 am<span class="gen"></span> Post subject: </span></td>
				<td valign="top" nowrap="nowrap"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/posting.php?mode=quote&p=173143&sid=4bc0edd9d9a2a9d9ee3b657c402a4f16"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_quote.gif" alt="Reply with quote" title="Reply with quote" border="0"/></a>   </td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><hr/></td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><span class="postbody">yeah you've definitly done a nice job of setting it up for a night scene, just one other thing I noticed this morning is the alpha planes on the trees dont look very cleen it looks like you painted the alphachannel with an airbrush, but im sure you're aware of them, you could probably get away them being all modeled.
<br/><br/>
I think the bricks need a sharper normalmap, Id suggest projecting it from a high poly model and give it some variation, I imagine you're going to be doing alot of projecting anyway with the scrolling ornaments.<br/>_________________<br/><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?p=160978#160978" target="_blank" class="postlink">Tutorial; Baking Multiple Maps in 3dsmax8. </a></span><span class="gensmall"/></td>
			</tr></table></td>
	</tr><tr><td class="row1" width="150" align="left" valign="middle"><span class="nav"><a href="viewtopic.php?p=172656#top" class="nav">Back to top</a></span></td>
		<td class="row1" width="100%" height="28" valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap"><table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" height="18" width="18"><tr><td valign="middle" nowrap="nowrap"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/profile.php?mode=viewprofile&u=5145&sid=4bc0edd9d9a2a9d9ee3b657c402a4f16"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_profile.gif" alt="View user's profile" title="View user's profile" border="0"/></a> <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/privmsg.php?mode=post&u=5145&sid=4bc0edd9d9a2a9d9ee3b657c402a4f16"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_pm.gif" alt="Send private message" title="Send private message" border="0"/></a>     <script language="JavaScript" type="text/javascript"><![CDATA[<!--

	if ( navigator.userAgent.toLowerCase().indexOf('mozilla') != -1 && navigator.userAgent.indexOf('5.') == -1 && navigator.userAgent.indexOf('6.') == -1 )

	else

	</tr><tr><td class="spaceRow" colspan="2" height="1"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/spacer.gif" alt="" width="1" height="1"/></td>
	</tr><tr><td width="150" align="left" valign="top" class="row2"><span class="name"><a name="173153"/><b>parsonsbear</b></span><br/><span class="postdetails">missed 400 shots<br/><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/images/avatars/upload/5309092814365b0dc6944a.gif" alt="" border="0"/><br/><br/>Joined: 06 Jan 2005<br/>Posts: 427<br/></span><br/></td>
		<td class="row2" width="100%" height="28" valign="top"><table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0"><tr><td width="100%"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?p=173153&sid=4bc0edd9d9a2a9d9ee3b657c402a4f16#173153"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/icon_minipost.gif" width="12" height="9" alt="Post" title="Post" border="0"/></a><span class="postdetails">Posted: Fri Mar 16, 2007 1:25 am<span class="gen"></span> Post subject: </span></td>
				<td valign="top" nowrap="nowrap"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/posting.php?mode=quote&p=173153&sid=4bc0edd9d9a2a9d9ee3b657c402a4f16"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_quote.gif" alt="Reply with quote" title="Reply with quote" border="0"/></a>   </td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><hr/></td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><span class="postbody">The bricks did get projected from geom, but the bevels need to be tighter, also got pulled into a sculpter and blurred them with a smooth brush while stamping, just playing around. 
<br/><br/>
The alphas on the trees are a lot sharper than that, but they get downsampled at distance so they turn blurry- for these, the geom is probably enough, but that won't work for the pines.
<br/><br/>
dropped a new skybox and starting to test ground work:
<br/><br/><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://a.parsons.edu/~evan/yerkes/snowtest.jpg" border="0"/></span><span class="gensmall"/></td>
			</tr></table></td>
	</tr><tr><td class="row2" width="150" align="left" valign="middle"><span class="nav"><a href="viewtopic.php?p=172656#top" class="nav">Back to top</a></span></td>
		<td class="row2" width="100%" height="28" valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap"><table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" height="18" width="18"><tr><td valign="middle" nowrap="nowrap"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/profile.php?mode=viewprofile&u=12142&sid=4bc0edd9d9a2a9d9ee3b657c402a4f16"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_profile.gif" alt="View user's profile" title="View user's profile" border="0"/></a> <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/privmsg.php?mode=post&u=12142&sid=4bc0edd9d9a2a9d9ee3b657c402a4f16"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_pm.gif" alt="Send private message" title="Send private message" border="0"/></a>   <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/aim:goim?screenname=cptincog&message=Hello+Are+you+there?"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_aim.gif" alt="AIM Address" title="AIM Address" border="0"/></a>  <script language="JavaScript" type="text/javascript"><![CDATA[<!--
